title: uk lockdown end tests self isolation rules relax
story: BRITAIN remains in full lockdown in a bid to limit the spread of coronavirus.The restrictions were put in place by Prime Minister Boris Johnson on March  as they look to protect the NHS and save lives from Covid-.Social distancing is one of the measures, where people need to remain two metres apart and only leave their homes for essential trips such as visit the supermarket or one exercise a day.And while all Brits are looking forward to ing to some form of normalcy, the Health Secretary Matt Hancock and top medical professionals revealed the five points that will need to be met before relaxing the lockdown rules.It was reported on Sunday, April , that Boris Johnson could set out his plan to ease the lockdown before the May  deadline.The Prime Minister, who ed to work on Monday, April , has already discussed with ministers the idea of modying the lockdown restrictions before the deadline.Any change to the UK lockdown will involve tweaking it rather than lting it.Its understood that restrictions will stay in place evenworkplaces and schools reopen.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealA vaccine for Covid- is the ultimate goal but is likely to take at least six months to a year before its made available.Meanwhile, testing is of the utmost importance - with hopes being pinned on the antibody test, which can tella person has had the disease and is immune to it.So what needs to happen before lockdown can be lted On Monday, May , Mr Hancock was joined by Professor Jonathan Van-Tam in the daily coronavirus press briefing.The Deputy Chief Medical Officer for England laid out a five-point criteria of what needs to be done or met before relaxing the lockdown restrictions.This is an area that has already largely been met around the country, as hospitals begin to feel an ease of strain.Field hospitals were set up to help them deal with this pressure, like the Nightingale Hospital at the London ExCel Arena.It was set up in early April with a capacity of , beds - but on May , it was placed on standby and stopping admissions, as it currently only has  patients recovering from coronavirus.Similar has happened at the other temporary hospitals across the UK, with Manchester, Birmingham, Cardf, Glasgow and Belfast also having centres.The UKs daily death toll hit its peak on April  when nearly , people died in and out of hospital due to coronavirus.Yet, since the start of May, deaths have fallen each day including  on May  - the lowest rise in five weeks.Although this still needs to be lowered, the consistent fall provides hopes that Covid- is becoming manageable and the end is in sight.The infection rate remains over the , new cases limit - which has been seen as the target level before lockdown measures will be eased.On May , the increase in cases rose by , - a decrease of less than  from the previous day.Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty revealed at the beginning of May that lockdown would remain in place until daily coronavirus cases fell below the , limit.This is one of the most pressing concerns at the moment with hospitals still looking to get their hands on Personal Protective Equipment .NHS staff around the country have been pushing for the government to bring in more PPE, with some even needing to hold their breath and wear bin bags in their attempts to prevent from catching the virus.As for testing, this can be broken down into the swab tests and the antibody versions.Swab tests are currently being carried out either at home or at one of the drive through centres with Matt Hancock revealed that over million have been carried out, including , on Sunday - which the Health Secretary expected to be lower than his , target.This test is currently available to million people, notably those that are key workers, their families and those with symptoms.Yet, antibody tests have been considered a key component to limiting the coronavirus spread, as it would showsomeone has had the killer bug and whether they are immune.There is not currently an approved antibody test, but Mr Hancock did reveal some people - including himself - are receiving regular blood tests to seethey have antibodies for coronavirus in their system.The final test is that the government and medical professionals must be certain that there will not be a risk of a second wave of infection, similar to that in Germany.Professor Van-Tam said on May : We have to be confident that the adjustments we contemplate are not going to risk a second peak of infections and this is really a matter of deep scientic discussion.Its one we are keeping under detailed scientic review as the days and weeks go by.Mr Hancock outlined the new contact tracing app in the press briefing, which is being trialled in Isle of Wight.This noties peoplethey have come into close contact with someone who later tests positive for coronavirus or is showing symptoms.It allows people to quickly self-isolate before spreading it further.The strategy was successful in other countries including South Korea, where less than  people have died from Covid-.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: douglas murray we need to make china pay
story: JUST one trouble with conspiracies is that they sometimes turn out to be true. Especially when you are dealing with a government like China’s.As viewers of the series Chernobyl know, non-democratic governments have a history of covering up their errors.In that case, the Soviets did everything they could to stop the world learning about the meltdown at their nuclear reactor.Today the Communist Party of China has done everything it can to hide what happened in Wuhan. Especially the origins of the disease which has shut down the world.Yesterday President Trump broke one of the taboos in all this. Which is needed.The question is: What is the likelihood the coronavirus originated in the exact part of China that has a laboratory looking into just such viruses To date the Chinese authorities have allowed the world to believe in the bat-eating, wet-market theory on the origins of the epidemic.They prefer embarrassment over suspicion.But all along, people have wondered whether something less “accidental” is at play.Now the US President has told reporters he has seen strong evidence that Covid- originated from the laboratory in Wuhan. The President’s remarks change the game.China should be in enough trouble as it is. Evenit was true that the virus is an accident caused by a strange food custom, the Chinese Communist Party has a lot to answer for.Why did it keep the news of the virus to itself for so many weeks  Why did it pretend it is not lethal as we now know it is Or pretend that it was hard to transmit  Why did they refuse to allow in inspectors from the World Health Organisation And why have the WHO now been refused inclusion in China’s own investigation into the origins of Covid- Questions also remain over the WHO’s seeming collusion with China over the crisis.The CCP’s actions would be bad enoughthe virus came from a wet market. But it must know that it is in a whole dferent realm of troublethe virus turns out to have come from its lab.If the CCP knew all along the virus had leaked from there then its cover-up is even more appalling. Because it means they knew exactly what they — and soon the world — were dealing with.But in the absence of trust-worthy information, darker and wilder theories take shape in the shadows. For example, could the virus have come from the Wuhan lab and been released deliberately To those deeply skeptical of the CCP, it’s not hard to believe it might have done that.They are in a trade war with America with a President who was making them lose. Now the CCP has managed to shut down the entire US economy with a virus.The question for the rest of the world will soon be simple: What to do about this There are several steps. The first is to try to determine exactly how this virus came about. To have an international  look into every possible cause. With no area of inquiry ruled out.That  should also investigate how the communist regime lied their way through this virus. We need to learn just how they managed to make a local problem into a global one.Then there is the question of what price they should pay. For accidental or not, there is no way that the CCP should be allowed to get away with this.Goodness knows they have tried. Throughout this crisis there have been a set of PR gestures by the Chinese authorities.The government and government-linked firms such as Huawei have made a big show of donating masks and other equipment.It is dismal. Like watching somebody who has just burned down your house offering you a watering can.Last month, German newspaper Bild infuriated China by suggesting Beijing should pay reparations for the coronavirus pandemic.It printed an “invoice’ for nearly billion eurosleading the Chinese embassy in Berlin to accuse the paper of stirring up prejudice.But once the engine of the other global economies — including ours — roars back into motion, we must make China pay.We must re-think our relationship with them. We should recognise the country is not just a competitor but a liability.We must punish them for the large-scale theft of information from British and American businesses it has engaged in for years.We must do whatever we can to disrupt their “belt-and-road” empire-building, which the CCP has worked its way into, and “bought up” small and poor countries.But it is not only such countries that are at the mercy of China and its President Xi Jinping. We may be in Britain too.Before this Wuhan disaster kicked off, our Government approved Huawei to provide part of our G capability.All of our allies warned against this. Our intelligence-sharing partners in the Five Eyes networkall strongly warned the British Government against allowing a firm that is indistinguishable from the CCP from having such access.Experience shows Chinese firms cannot be trusted to provide such sensitive — and strategic — technology.The Huawei decision was a rare misstep by the Johnson government. Now is the time to correct it.We do not need to provoke China. But nor do we need to pander to it. And we should not be putting our future security in their hands.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Trade sanctions may be the only way to make the CCP understand just how much damage it has done to the UK and global economy.Whatever the origins of this virus, we must show China that there is a cost to lying on this scale.A cost to causing the whole world to be locked in our homes. title: instagram celebs boasting lockdown
story: THIS week, the actor Chris Hemsworth was photographed with his agreeable-looking child, in the sunshine, outside their beachfront home in the exclusive Australian surfing resort of Byron Bay.And I guess everyone thought when they saw the picture: “Well, lockdown’s working pretty well for him.”Yeah, and it can’t be too bad either for Mrs Hemsworth. Living by the sea, in paradise, with a triangular- torsoed Hollywood hunk.But thenyou take a glance at your social media, you’ll notice that absolutely everyone  is living the Hemsworth dream.It’s an endless parade of people’s perfect sourdough baking and of jolly board games with the kids.This morning, my Instagram feed featured a young family doing a fancy dress dinner, a girl on an enormous horse, a woman sprawled on the bonnet of a Mercedes SL, a man with a cute dog, doing exercises, and a shot of some cows taken through a wisteria bush.On Instagram, no one is ever bored, it never rains and everyone’s breasts are perfect. Especially Chris Hemsworth’s.This is having an effect on the nation’s teenagers. They have been told there will be no exams this year and that all their school work was for nothing. They’ve been told they have to stay indoors and that they can’t see their friends.And it’s driving them mad because they do not read newspapers. They do not listen to the BBC news. And they replaced Radio  with Spoty five years ago.This means they never hear any actual news. So they don’t know what’s going on.Instead they look at their phonesand all they can see are pretty girls with swimsuits up their a*** cheeks, and Chris Hemsworth, and parents who have turned the cellar into a nightclub and lots of cute ducklings.And they’re thinking, as they watch the rain trickle down the windows at their house: “Why can’t I have some of that ”But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.In the olden days we’d have smacked their bottoms and told them to stop being spoiled, but that’s not allowed any more. So I’ve come up with another idea . . .If you are an old person stuck in a tower block, waiting for Covid- to stick its warty little head through the letterbox, post a picture of your surroundings on Instagram. Don’t hold back. Show us the overflowing cat litter and the photograph of your husband, alone in his hospital bed.Show us also pictures of your sister who is in a care home and hasn’t had a visitor for five weeks.And your food cupboard which has nothing in it any more. And your empty bottle of Senokot.In fact, we should all get in on the act. Don’t wait for a joyous moment to photograph and share. Send us instead pictures of stuff you didn’t enjoy.The particularly gruesome bit of wax you’ve just pulled out of your left ear. The turd your dog just did on the mat. Your fat other half slobbing out in front of the TV.Your kids throwing Monopoly pieces at one another after a row over Fenchurch Street station.Instead of sharing your perfect loaf, send pictures of the charred wreck that went wrong, the scarf full of dropped stitches, the wonky self-assembly garden furniture that broke the first time you sat on it.Hit us with the reality of lockdown. Admit that it’s one part happiness and nine parts ditch water.And then maybe teenagers will start to understand that le is bookended by the lucky and the not so lucky. At one end you’ve got the Hemsworths. At the other you’ve got a frightened old man in a tenement block in Bermondsey.Maybe then they will understand they are somewhere in the middle, and stop bloody complaining.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.There is much debate about what increases your chances of dying from Covid-.Well, I don’t know about you but I’ve addressed the issue by sitting on a sofa for six hours a day, eating slabs of Cadbury’s Fruit  Nut chocolate and getting up only to go to the fridge for another bottle of wine.I guess I’m working on the principle that soon I’ll be so fat, there won’t be room in the house for me and the virus as well.But there is one problem.There are now so many empty bottles sitting by the bins at the bottom of the drive I just know my neighbours will assume I’ve been throwing illegal parties, and call the police.A nurse made headlines this week after moaning about the cramped conditions on a London Tube train at .am.She said she was risking her le at work and pointed out that she shouldn’t have to risk it even more while commuting. Fair point, you might think. But hang on.In the olden days – before March – people may well have been on a Tube train at that time because they were coming home from a club.But these days, nobody on a Tube train at quarter to six in the morning is there for fun. They’re ALL going to work.There’s nothing wrong with that. It’s what most of us have been told to do all along. But I do agree that commuting on a cramped Tube is bloody dangerous.So I ask once again for parking restrictions to be lted immediately, as this would allow people to go to work in the blissful self-isolation of their own cars.I WAS told this week, by The Times newspaper no less, that this summer’s must-have accessory is a straw handbag. No it isn’t.As no one’s looking and no one’s going out, this year’s must-have accessory is the pyjama bottom teamed with odd socks.An aerial photograph of Portsmouth taken this week showed that the colour of the sea has turned from the usual mud brown to a shimmering, aquamarine blue.It’s the sort of colour you usually associate with the Caribbean, and it is genuinely amazing.Naturally, green people are saying it happened because the lockdown means less traffic. And they may be right.Or, let me just lob this one in . . .  it happened because the photographer was experimenting with some of the filters on his new phone.My phone’s got so many thatyou gave me long enough, I could take a selfie and make me look like Chris Hemsworth. Or his we. A MINISTER in the South African government an ounced this week that his country has plenty of PPE for front-line health workers and that all patients with Covid- will be given “vibrators”.I think he meant “ventilators”.If he didn’t, well, I guess they’ll die happy.For the past couple of years, farmers have not been allowed to spray their bright yellow oil seed rape with insecticides called neonicotinoids.As a result, a lot of my crop is dead.But on the upside, I’m now seeing more bumble bees than I have in years. And yesterday I saw a tortoiseshell butterfly, the first I’ve found since about .But that said, my eyesight is so bad these days, it could have been an actual tortoise.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: david blunkett lockdown decisions government must make
story: Substitute the word politics for socialism and it is immediately obvious that prioritising in the coronavirus crisis poses almost impossible choices for the leadership of our country in moving to recovery.Recovery not just for our economy, but also for our social well-being and the normalisation of everyday le which makes living worthwhile.This week Boris Johnson promised that in the coming days he would set out a menu of options for a phasedto some form of normality in the weeks ahead.But the balance between lting the lockdown too quickly and failing to appreciate the long-term detrimental impact on every aspect of our lives, of the delay in ing to near normality, requires the wisdom of Solomon.Almost  years ago, when I became Home Secretary, Islamist terrorists launched their attack on the World Trade Center in New York.Almost , people lost their lives in one day and the immediate expectation was that there would be an attack here in the UK, most probably in London.When we met as a Cabinet, decisions had to be taken immediately as to whether to lock down the capital in the anticipation that lives might be lost in the days ahead.Steady nerves prevailed as we realised that the damage we would do to ourselves would be far greater than that which might be inflicted by our enemies.That is why, with our hearts in our mouths, we encouraged people to go to work and continue their lives as normal while taking every possible step behind the scenes to put in measures to protect us from attack.The virus is very dferent and the choices to be made are more dficult.Distancing and social isolation were clearly the right measure to put in place six weeks ago to reduce the transmission of infection, the pressure on the NHS and, above all, the loss of le.Whether or not the organised supply of PPE and the rapid expansion of testing was a failure of government is for another day — but what isn’t is the careful steps needed to get us out of this lockdown.Because while opinion polling shows not only public support for caution, but also anxiety about ing to work and social contact, the potential irreparable damage to our economy will hurt all of us.The job of politicians is to hear but then to balance alternative conclusions from the experts — as Winston Churchill put it: “Scientists should be on tap, but not on top.”In our democracy, leaders need to gain consent but they also have to assess and take risks. If the current measures start to erode, unforeseen dangers could arise.Yet, move too quickly and you risk being blamed for getting it wrong.In some form continuing to isolate without isolation will be necessary, but avoiding great damage to the most disadvantaged children, many of whom are receiving no schooling at all, is vital for our future.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Equally, preventing the potential shortening of the lives of older people through continuing inactivity and lack of social contact must form part of the equation.In the end it isn’t those appearing on TV and radio, often with contradictory analysis and advice, but elected politicians who must do the right thing.Carefully, conscientiously but bravely they must now lead us out of the unsustainable lockdown which, while necessary at the time, could,prolonged, be a more damaging medicine than the original disease.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus women equal leadership
story: AS I have often pointed out, there are many reasons why women make good leaders.In my experience, they tend to be good collaborators because their ego is unlikely to interfere with letting other people have good ideas, and be able to voice them and take credit for them.Their emotional intelligence and empathy makes them excellent communicators.But it’s not just my view that women are good leaders. Many studies show women are more focused on building community and teams.They are more likely than men to cultivate a erse set of advisers to help them succeed. They are also more likely to follow advice.A study by management consulting firm McKinsey found that women are more people- orientated and spend more time developing and coaching other leaders in their organisation. In other words, they don’t need to reserve all the glory for themselves.There is something  at play too, though. Female leaders are more likely to be blameddecisions are unpopular or ineffective. They are questioned and second-guessed more often than men.But then Covid- entered the equation and presented world leaders with a new challenge — an invisible enemy that is highly contagious, unpredictable and deadly.This pandemic has been an unprecedented test for all concerned.And guess what  A disproportionate number of those who have passed this test — countries such as Germany, New Zealand, Iceland and Finland — have women at the helm.It is not exclusively female-led countries that are doing well, of course. But bearing in mind only seven per cent of all world leaders are women, about  per cent of countries led by women are doing well when it comes to containing Covid-. Global health experts have concluded that one thing that has led to success in tackling coronavirus is — speed.Prof Tom Bollyky, director of global health programme at US think-tank the Council on Foreign Relations, said: “Countries that have not dithered in their response, that have mobilised quickly, have done well.”New Zealand’s PM Jacinda Ardern put it simply: “Go hard and go early.”The number of Covid--related deaths is predicted to be substantially lower in areas where leaders acted sooner, even by a week, because they flattened the curve and prevented new cases.Many women acted first and made the brave decision to shut down le as we knew it, even though that was an unpopular thing to do.But it seems women leaders are listening to World Health Organisation advice and also looking at other countries for guidance.They don’t think they have all the answers but women are able to put their ego to one side and let experts guide them — something which cannot be said of Donald Trump.Incidentally, I have not seen any women leaders making unfounded or dangerous suggestions about possible cures. Can you imagine a woman leader suggesting that people inject Dettol into themselves, as dingbat Trump recently suggested Or can you imagine a woman suggesting to people that they can fight coronavirus and winthey are strong enough This pandemic is not a battle to be fought and won. It is a virus, which can affect literally anyone.No one knows how they will be affected and that bullish “fight it” approach is, in my experience, very male. Conversely, the decision to protect everyone, putting the most at risk first, is more female.It’s interesting that some male leaders seem more interested in covering up the problems. Like Donald Trump, who thinks he is an expert on everything and more fixated on garnering praise for what he has done than fixing and getting right what has not gone so well.I know I am talking in generalisations here but my experience of women is that we want to understand the mistakes and fix them, not cover them up.This pandemic has been full of dficulty and tragedy for everyone.But perhaps one good thing that will come out of it is that the world will acknowledge women deserve an equal  when it comes to leadership.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.FORMER Love Islander Montana Brown this week posted some “Instagram vs reality” pictures ­– one of her in a lacy bralette and silky shorts, the other in a cute pink PJ set.But I couldn’t help but notice that she is wearing  eyelashes and full make-up in bed – in both sets.The very idea of wearing make-up, let alone  eyelashes at the moment, is unimaginable – especially to go to sleep.A far more realistic picture of my le at present, in fact, is that I am mainly wearing pyjamas all day as well as in bed.HAS anyone  been watching Madonna’s “Quarantine Diaries” on Instagram This week she said she has coronavirus antibodies, having been tested for the virus.And her conclusion in the face of this discovery  “Tomorrow, I’m going to go for a long drive in a car and I’m going to roll down the window, and I’m going to breathe in the Covid- air,” she says.Sorry, but what  No one knows yet whether it’s possible to have coronavirus more than once and the presence of antibodies may not provide protection against the disease.This seems like a risk no one should be advocating.The bonny baby, who has already inherited his father’s hair, was named after both their grandfathers and the doctor who saved Boris’s le.A wonderful and touching gesture.Wilfred, a name not popular since the s, takes its roots from “will” and “peace”, two words very apt for these dficult times.HUGE congratulations to Gigi Hadid and Zayn Malik, who confirmed this week they are expecting a baby.I guess the lockdown baby boom has already started, which just proves that le goes on.What a beautul baby they will have.It’s great to have some good news amid the gloom.WHAT a month it’s been for Boris Johnson.For the past few weeks he has faced professional challenges far bigger than those he may have anticipated when he was first elected Prime Minister.Not only that, but he has also survived time in intensive care suffering from coronavirus. And now he is a father yet again at .I think it’s fair to say that this period will go down in his own personal history as perhaps some of the most memorable few weeks of his le.EVEN the most hardened climate change denier cannot fail to pause for thought at the before and after photos of the Solent.Aerial shots of this part of Britain’s coastline look more like pictures that have been taken in the Caribbean.The water is so blue and so clean that it looks positively tropical. In fact, it’s unrecognisable after just six weeks of lockdown.The images show how the usually murky waters of the UK coastline have been transformed, which must surely be due in part to a reduction in pollution since the coronavirus pandemic stopped leisure traffic on the Solent.But other astonishing photos from all over the world have surfaced recently too.Pollution-free images of landmarks in Delhi and Beijing, which are all too often seen shimmering under a haze of smog, are a real reminder of our role in creating pollution and also in reducing it.Imagineanother silver lining to this terrible pandemic was that we all began to understand the effects of our impact on the environment, and that we took the threat of climate change more seriously – and started to take responsibility for changing our ways.I AM as keen as the next person to regain my freedom, and for things to begin toto normal.But I cannot be the only one who gave a shudder at the thought of being allowed to choose a “bubble” of just ten family members as friends, as was hinted at by some.Can you even imagine the disputes, upsets and hurt feelings that would result all over the landyour chosen bubble had chosen another group to huddle with In fact, that rule would likely cause so much offence that we would only have ten friends left. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: china truth coronavirus truth opinion
story: AN emotional Boris Johnson described how close he came to leaving this world, just as his new baby son was about to enter it.He was near tears as he told The Sun on Sunday’s David Wooding about the moment he realised he might die. “I’m a very lucky man,” he said.Our Prime Minister was indeed lucky.He was almost killed by a hideous bug we have learned to call coronavirus. Or Covid-.It should be known unflinchingly as “Chinese flu”.This virus was born in China, covered up by China, spread worldwide by China.In American bric-a-brac shops you will see signs saying: “You break it, you own it.” Covid- is owned by China.Chinese flu has paralysed the global economy, brought poverty to whole nations and increased the risk of death and disaster across the planet from other causes.The world is in lockdown, we are wearing face masks and latex gloves, avoiding friends and family, thanks to China.To avoid perhaps even more lethal pandemics, China must be brought to book.Beijing must allow us to find out precisely how this virus escaped, whether from a leaky laboratory or its hideous wet markets in Wuhan.The first indication of coronavirus was monitored as far back as November last year.China must explain why it silenced the doctor who raised the alarm and why it allowed millions of Chinese New Year revellers to travel far and wide long after learning the disease spread from human to human.Far from addressing these issues, China is doing everything possible to wriggle off the hook.Belligerent attacks, sanctioned by the Chinese Communist Party, are levelled against any country or inidual who dares ask questions.In an extraordinary outburst, China’s ambassador to Canberra threatened to beggar the Australian economy by cutting off trade in coal and wine.Similar warnings have been heard in Germany about car exports.Their crime  To call for a transparent investigation into the origins of this lethal pandemic.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal. Beijing’s aggression is working.The EU allegedly watered down criticism of the regime in a major report on President Donald Trump cites top-level intelligence that this bug began le in the Wuhan Institute of Virology.Nobody wants to hear inconvenient truth from Trump.So as a near-death survivor, it now falls to Boris Johnson, with his freshly enhanced international authority, to pick up the baton and lead the world in demanding answers.As he told ministers at his first Cabinet meeting, quoting his Roman hero Cicero: “The health of the people comes first.”He can start once this crisis has subsided by cancelling Britain’s reckless deal to give China’s state-backed Huawei a role in building our new G broadband network.The idea that heavily subsidised Huawei is independent of Beijing’s snooping rulers was always absurd.After the Covid meltdown, there is zero chance Tory MPs will vote this through Parliament.The world, brave Australia included, is rapidly reviewing its reliance on cheap Chinese supply lines.Beijing will scream blue murder, of course.But as the Chinese like to say, every crisis presents an opportunity.Boris should make a virtue of necessity and turn this “new normal” attitude to China into official Government policy.The World Health Organisation, heavily reliant on Chinese cash and goodwill, is also in the dock.This UN body is supposed to protect the world from perils such as coronavirus.Instead, its pro-China leaders turned a blind eye until way too late.China must not be allowed to bully or buy its way out of this mess — or to “save face” at the expense of countless millions of lives, now or in the future.China must be held to account.Having left his death bed full of “terrible buoyancy”, Boris Johnson is just the man to do it.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for four-bedroom, three bathroom house in Youngsville was built in the s.But its spine-chilling reputation is seemingly throwing a spanner in its current owners attempt to get rid of it, despite trying to give it away.McLain Investments co-owner Sylvia McLain shared three snaps of the house on Facebook to convince a suitor to move it and restore it so they could build a new property on the title: meet three community heroes who are helping others
story: In times of trouble people need their best friends beside them, and that’s never more true than for the homeless community and their dogs.So when, in March, some of London’s nearly , rough sleepers were offered hotel accommodation to escape the ravages of the coronavirus pandemic, many were worried about leaving their canine companions behind.“Homeless people’s dogs are their leline,” says Michelle Clark, who founded Dogs on the Streetsfour years ago.The charity operates a mobile vet clinic for street dogs in London, offering check-ups, medication, leads, bowls, blankets and toys as well as a   freephone number for pets requiring urgent medical attention.“When the country went into lockdown we were approached by local councils as some of the hotels didn’t accept dogs,” Michelle, , from London, explains.“No problem – we’d just set up a -kennel sanctuary so we were able to tell rough sleepers that, while they stayed safe in hotels, we’d care for their pets. Still, saying goodbye to their companions was devastating for people. Their dogs are their company, love, loyalty and trust – their everything. Driving the dog away, I’d burst into tears.”Six weeks into lockdown the owners are missing their dogs, but Michelle sends them daily pictures and videos to reassure them.“Some of the dogs slept in the bottom of their owners’ sleeping bags so we bought sleeping bags for them to burrow into,” Michelle says. “Others preferred to be on top of duvets. Their kennels are heated and during the day we keep the dogs busy, playing in our three acres of grounds, so there’s no time to pine for their owners.”One dog – Miss L, a young husky – is a case in point. Her owner was distraught when he said goodbye to her – they’d been together since she was eight weeks old – and he was worried about how she’d cope without him. But Michelle discovered she loves cheese, which helped gain her trust, and now Miss L is settled in, making friends with fellow lockdown pups.Some homeless people, however, couldn’t face being parted from their canine companions so remained on the streets. Michelle and her team are there to support them too.“We’re operating the mobile clinic as a food bank for dogs, and the   emergency line,” Michelle says. “We’ve had people in dire financial straits contact us saying they can’t afford to keep their dogs and we’ve organised food parcels so they can stay together.”In the current crisis, working on the streets, Michelle and her volunteers are effectively on the front line. A medical supply company donated gloves and masks and Deborah Meaden sent hand sanitisers to help them.Still, Michelle has been diagnosed with pneumonia, possibly Covid- related, and is recovering at home with her ex-street dog Brock by her side while her team continue DOTS’ work.“I just want to get better and back out there, helping the homeless community,” Michelle says. “There will be some emotional reunions when this is over.”When British schools went into Covid- lockdown, a nationwide network of teachers, including Sandra Obike, stepped up to support NHS heroes.Sandra, who is head of design and technology at Swanlea School in east London, immediately put her skills and workspace to best use – first, sourcing spare unused personal protective equipmentthat could be donated to a nearby major hospital, and then using her school design and technologylab to create  brand new visors for key workers.And she isn’t alone – DT staff at more than  British schools are now collectively involved in the fight against Covid-, manufacturing and donating more than , items of vital PPE including visors, goggles, scrubs, masks and more.“We’ve been doing things since the very first week of lockdown, communicating using sites like Facebook, sharing resources and free design templates,” explains Sandra.“I asked our school headteacherwe could use the materials, space and machinery, and she instantly said yes. I also had a contact at Royal London Hospital, and asked: ‘Can I help  Would it be useful to have some visors ’, and she jumped at the chance.“I knew immediately that we had some unused PPE like goggles, aprons and gloves – so we sent that to the hospital at the start of April, so they were able to start using it as soon as possible.”Sandra, her boyfriend and one of her DT colleagues then set to work at school, creating new visors while safely observing social distancing. They used open-source design templates – provided for free by expert companies like Kitronik and Smoke  Mirrors, who’ve also been key to this Covid- effort – and their ingenuity with the materials they already had.“We were working pretty much like an assembly line, cutting the material, sterilising the parts, assembling it all and then bagging everything for delivery,” says Sandra.“As a teacher, I’m now working from home and interacting with students, but making visors was something I could do while still continuing my day-to-day job. I felt like it was something I could do in the interim, to keep key workers safe, while there was a shortage of PPE.”It’s clear that Sandra is passionate about her DT teaching profession: “We’re educating the engineers of the future,” she says.There’s also no doubt that creating visors is for her a very personal response: “A lot of my family members and friends work within the NHS, as doctors and nurses,” she says. “My mum is retired, but still helping out in a care home. As technologists, we’re problem-solvers – we try to work around the issue, and find a way to do things. For instance, we’ve got two large-scale laser cutters at our school, which meant we could cut quite a bit in a short scale of time, and some places have used D printers – so you work to the best ability that you’ve got.”Teamwork is at the heart of this story, too. This is about colleagues and collaborators, from dedicated DT teachers to suppliers who donate materials free of charge.“Social media has mobilised our effort, on a national scale,” says Sandra. “Where there is surplus, we’ll try to logistically pass it around the network across Britain. Seeing the sheer numbers of what people have done and contributed – that’s when it hits home how amazing this is.“As a teacher, this is a small thing I can do, so that someone who’s potentially putting their le at risk can go into a safer situation at work, and do something big. Everyone is working together for that common goal. It goes to show how much we love the NHS, and how much we want to step out to support them.”Big-hearted Brits are making a dference to other people’s lives every day in this time of crisis – and sometimes it’s the little things that mean the most.Five-year-old Lucy Dawson has been busy delivering handmade paper flowers to her neighbours in Fakenham in Norfolk – leaving them with a note on their doorsteps in the hope of raising a smile and lting people’s spirits during the lockdown.“I learnt to make the paper flowers at my breakfast and after-school club before the lockdown. I wanted to cheer people up,” Lucy says.Her parents, Shelley, , and Marc, , couldn’t be prouder of their daughter, who’s received chocolate and cards from grateful neighbours.Lucy says: “I felt happy and proud that I helped to cheer people up. It gave me happy tears.”Mum Shelley says: “Lucy is creative and loves crafting. She suggested leaving the flowers on doorsteps with a note as a little surprise.”For many neighbours, locked down until the coronavirus has passed, a surprise gt has been the highlight of their day.Lucy and her mum have been careful to observe social distancing and to make the doorstep deliveries during their daily exercise session, using plenty of hand sanitising gel along the way.Shelley says: “She’s a caring little girl. Her grandad Andrew, who’s , lives next door and we can’t see him at the moment. So she leaves handmade gts on his doorstep because she misses him so much.”One note from a neighbour was wrapped around a chocolate bar, and said: “This is just a little thank you from us, it made us smile and we really needed that today.”Dad Marc adds: “We’re extremely proud of what Lucy has done for her neighbours. The look on her face when she received the thank you gts and notes is something me and Shelley will never forget.”A neighbour who works as an AE nurse in King’s Lynn was especially touched when she discovered Lucy’s flowers on her doorstep. She and her family wrote a note of thanks.The Dawsons needed something to feel good about. Shelley was meant to start a new job as a commercial property manager this month but it fell through because of the coronavirus crisis, while Marc has been furloughed from his job as a mechanical supervisor.“We’re busy home schooling and trying to keep Lucy busy,” he says. “She’s an only child and I think she’s getting a bit bored! She misses her friends but she’s working hard at her reading, writing and maths – and she and I love to play football in the garden.”The Dawsons are Norwich City fans, so they were delighted when Lucy won a Community Hero award from the club recently for her flower initiative.And she’s not stopping there. Lucy’s planning to leave handmade cards on neighbours’ doorsteps next.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Kim is believed to have about  signicant compounds around the country, and numerous luxury vessels.NK News - which focuses on North Korean news - said that new satellite imagery reveals the megaship with an Olympic-size pool used at Kims Wonsan villa last summer.The website says the giant pleasure vessel boasts an  meter-long pool, multi-storey lounge and two huge figure-eight waterslides.Its not clear, however, whether the posh barge is either being decommissioned in Wonsan, or having a refurb.NK News has been comparing satellite pictures of the vessel, going back to  - the year that the US named North Korea as part of an axis of evil.Reuters reported on April  that satellite imagery showed recent movements of luxury boats often used by the North Korean leader and his entourage near Wonsan provided further indications he has been at the coastal resort while he was mysteriously missing.Kim’s seaside compound in Wonsan, on the country’s east coast, is dotted with guest villas and serviced by a private beach, basketball court, and private train station, according to experts and satellite imagery. An airstrip was bulldozed last year to build a horse riding track, while a boathouse nearby shelters Kim’s Princess  luxury yacht, valued at around  million in .Details of his waterpark were also revealed in a rare sketch done by Italian chef Ermanno Furlanis, who worked in Pyong-Yang for the dictator in .Former dictator Kim Jong-Il was often seen at the aquatic park with girls often spotted leaving the luxury barge in a boat.Chef Furlanis, who worked in North Korea for  days, said he had managed to catch glimpses of the barge despite authorities often turning his head so he could not see certain areas of the barge.He told The Sun four years ago: “I think it was for training of the swimmers. The athletes are held in great honour in the country.“They were young athletes, swimmers or basketers.”But he said he also believed the barge was used for “amusement” as well.The experienced chef, who has worked all over the globe, said: “ also some young girl, I saw two, one time the yacht of Kim Il Sung arrived from there.”He said he could not see the detail of the floating park as it wasnt near the kitchen.Cooking for Kim Jung-Il, the leader of North Korea in the late s, the chef said the structure featured a landing bay for smaller boats as well as three floors of accommodation, a guard tower and a waterslide into a pool.The rare sketch revealed that the aquatic park was mobile, moving through the hundreds of islands near the base.From his vantage point of the kitchens, Furlanis said he could see a guard tower on either side of the pool while there were rooms where people could stay and enjoy themselves.The chef said he enjoyed his time working there, telling The Sun: “They have been very polite and gentle with us.”He also said the people were highly refined, and that they appreciated his meals.But he was unable to see much more of the barge or the dictator himself.The chef recalled being ordered to turn his head to avoid seeing Kims yacht arrive.Furlanis said: “I could not even stare at him, they turned myin the other direction.“Nobody could stare at him. title: hidden cellar home plymouth
story: Jake Brown, from Plymouth, Devon, noticed one wall had dferent textures and decided to inspect further.He drilled a hole in the wall big enough to get his head through it to check the area.When he took a look, Jake discovered there was a huge cellar underneath his home, so he opened the wall to investigate.Inside the tunnel he discovered items including paint cans, a -year-old newspaper as well as bottles from the early s.Jake said: I recently moved into a Georgian property in Emma Place.While having a lazy coffee standing outside the basement front door of the property I noticed a patch in the wall of a texture dferent to the rest.I also noted that the patch was the same distance from the coal cellar already exposed, currently used for storage.Curiosity and a little boredom got the better of me, after which I grabbed a drill and began working pilot viewing holes into the wall.Once I had made two holes, one for viewing, one for a torch, I peered through into the dark dusty expanse and realised that it was another cavern of sorts.After realising what was beneath his house, Jake opened the wall up so that he could climb down and walk inside.He added: I proceeded to hammer out a larger opening through which I could get a better idea of the space, andI should carry on making mess.Upon creating a large enough hole to fit through, I shone a torch into the dark, revealing the larger than expected space before me.The cavern had a lot of builders waste from another era, so I climbed inside to explore and take a closer look.He soon realised the area was bigger than he had expected.Jake added: I measured the rough area of the space and observed its structural integrity.I was pleased to note that the stone arched ceiling was in great condition and the expanse measured a healthy m deep, m high, and m wide.In the area, Jake found piles of building waste and other rubbish, so started digging through it all for clues.He said: Upon inspection it confirmed that the space had been covered up for many years.It had been used as an easy space, to hide the waste from renovating the propertys roof, guttering, doors, and windows many years ago before being covered up.As I moved deeper into the cavern I began to search for evidence that would tie it to a grouping of years so as I could more accurately determine how long it had been covered up.In the dark I collected bottles, paint cans, and my golden find was the remains of a newspaper, though was more comparable to mushy silt.After preparing the newspaper in a bath filled with water, Jake was finally able to open a few pages in search of a date.He added: I laid the items I had collected out in the clear light to identy their age.The paint cans were extremely degraded but had enough detail to show that the labelling was of a s s era style.The bottles, after a quick wipe, were etched with detailing common also of the early s.The biggest reveal was the newspaper, it almost disintegrated upon human touch, so a CSI style method was used to carefully peel back the congealed layers.I proceeded to run a warm bath and soaked the congealed brown mess in the solution for a period of time, after which tweezers and vibration were used to slowly work shards of the paper free while submerged.After as many fragments of the paper had been recovered as possible, I photographed while still submerged and removed what was salvageable for drying.I scanned through the jumbled pieces looking for dates or usable information to determine the era.There were little hints the style of writing, no colour, picture style, currency and then finally a date!What was barely readable was the year , this along with the other pieces of evidence fitted, meaning the cellar had been blocked up for over  years.Armed with evidence, Jake contacted a historian friend, Richard Fisher, to ask for his input.Jake added: That evening I excitedly reached out to a local historian, Mr. Richard Fisher. I described the findings and asked his guidance.Richard said: The whole area before then was a large hill called Windridge Hill for obvious reasons.This was quarried away to almost high tide level, then the houses when built into the hole with cellars, undercrofts etc.However these early cellars, this one looks to be for coal, were built out not only underneath the pavement but out into the road.The load on the roads would have been much lighter than now.I have seen these places turned into wine cellars, a place to grow mushrooms, andbig enough, a grotto type bathing area...

title: brits urged rubbish tips queues demand
story: HOUSEHOLDERS are being urged not to rush to dumps when they reopen — amid concerns over long queues trying to get rid of lockdown rubbish.Many waste and recycling centres closed because they could not be operated within social distancing rules and to allow councils to focus on household waste collections.But concerns have been raised over an increase in fly-tipping.The Government has since said it wants to see councils reopen tips, with social distancing in place, but residents should only goit is essential.Greater Manchester is one of the areas where tips reopened.Long queues have been reported and across the country residents are being urged by councils to avoid rushing to tips and to “reduce, reuse and recycle” their rubbish wherever possible.The District Councils Network and County Councils Network have issued the warning as they fear a surge in demand.They say nearly all councils have reported higher than usual levels of waste in recent weeks.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Councils have seen reductions to their teams, as staff self-isolate and collections are disrupted by social distancing.Dan Humphreys, of the District Councils’ Network said: “It won’t be possible for everyone to suddenly get rid of rubbish they have built up over recent weeks all in one go.”Sam Corcoran, communities and environment spokesman for the County Councils Network, said: “We would encourage residents to only take a trip to their recycling centreabsolutely necessary.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cyclists coronavirus lockdown social distancing
story: CYCLISTS are being targeted by coronavirus vigilantes during the lockdown, with some suffering verbal abuse and others being injured, it has been reported.The UKs two biggest cyclist organisations have warned of a culture of hostility against those who take to the road to exercise.Cyclists in Somerset have been targeted by drawing pins placed on roads, while others have been injured by motorists speeding or carrying out close passes.Some signs warning cyclists against entering some villages have been spotted in several counties, including Cambridgeshire, Cheshire and Powys.One resident even daubed the sentence stay home cyclists covidiot on a road in the Chew Valley, Somerset, The Times reports.However, it is believed that many cyclists are being targeted because of concerns they are breaching social distancing rules - by riding in groups or far from their homes.Cycling UK and British Cycling have written a letter to The Times, saying they are concerned about an increasing number of reports of cyclists and cycling clubs being targeted and vilied while out riding.The alleged abuse led Sharrow Cycling Club, the oldest cycling group in Sheffield, to cancel organised rides, although some members still exercise alone - which has created furious reactions among local residents.Pete Collins, the club chairman, said: Many people are using the lockdown as an excuse to air their long-held grievances against cyclists, which in our case we believe to be unwarranted and unfair.Riders have cut their distances in half or more, are staying relatively local and are complying entirely with government guidelines on social distancing.Cycling is permitted as a form exercise during the coronavirus lockdown, with no fixed limits on how far or for how long people can ride.Cycling UK advises those who want to go out on their bikes to use common sense when planning your route - but still doing enough exercise to keep in good shape physically and mentally.British Cycling and Cycling UK said many people are also using their bikes to deliver prescriptions, raise money or feed families during the lockdown.They added: There is no trusted evidence to suggest that cyclists are any more likely to spread the disease than runners and walkers,they follow the social distancing requirements.However, the groups have asked the public to show tolerance, warmth and care towards those who get out on their bikes during this crisis.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.

title: joe wicks lockdown jamie oliver
story: RIGHT then, Joe Wicks. He’s just Jamie Oliver with a skipping rope, I assumed, before this wretched lockdown business began.A character we’ve all seen in our local park, with a pair of boxing gloves and a stopwatch, charging financial managers £ a haemorrhoid to do some sit-ups over by the ornamental lake.One of Britain’s ever-growing army of personal trainers who,he wasn’t bouncing around on YouTube every morning, would be clogging up Love Island or Ex On The Beach.That’s what I thought, anyway.Then the coronavirus hit, the local swimming pool shut, the man became a phenomenon and before I could come to my senses, Joe and his infernal timing device were beeping away in my living room, every morning, as I joined in his PE lesson. Inevitably, it didn’t last.First, Joe’s routine did me what I can only describe as “a mischief”.Then, one morning, aged , I caught sight of myself, in a picture frame, doing his “reverse frog shuffle” and thought: “Stuff this for type two diabetes. I’m out.”I’d got no closer to understanding Joe’s astonishing popularity, though, which is truly global.Over , people log in just to stare at his fairly spartan living room, every Monday to Friday.Hundreds of thousands more appear when Joe starts his  minutes of physical jerks.So, in an attempt to unlock the greatest mystery of the outbreak, I kept watching Joe and swtly came to the conclusion success was not linked to his presenting skills.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Because, for a host, he has a strangely distracted and chaotic air about him, with sessions regularly being interrupted by technical issues, forgetfulness and tiny daughter Indie, who charged in, dressed as Zog the dragon, on Friday.He’s not the greatest multitasker either, as Joe often demonstrates with the geography quiz he’s introduced to jolly things along.“What is the capital city of Moscow. . .   No. I mean Russia.”He also has to believe me when I tell him he’s not one of le’s natural comedians.“What’s the capital of Cuba  Fray Bentos. Nah, only joking.”The jokes need to go the same way as the viewers’ poems, in honour of Joe, which he was actually reading out loud, until modesty finally prevailed.Much safer ground is the “spot the dference” competition, which borders on insulting, when he’s merely placed his wall atlas upside down or swapped his electric guitar for a ukulele, but does hint at the drive, ambition and ego behind the man.One day he replaced the atlas with a picture of himself, the next with a picture of his “other house” in Los Angeles and suddenly the penny dropped.Joe’s loaded and his head is not just on its way to Hollywood, it’s already there, making movies and doing squat thrusts with Gwyneth and Brad.The weird thing is, in other presenters, soap actors or comedians, I’d roll my eyes at the folly.With Joe Wicks, I don’t. ’Cos I can’t help it, I quite like him.Part of that may be linked to his no-frills background and a level of personal generosity that’s way beyond most of us .But I like to think it’s got more to do with the fact that, at a time when other cynical, doom-mongering TV hosts are desperately trying to read the public mood, reinvent themselves and force their agenda on viewers, Joe Wicks is just doing what he’s always done. Sit-ups.He may not be Emily Maitlis , but he’s the irrepressible and lucky optimist telling us to get off our fat a***s when we need to hear it most.He’s temporarily indisposed at the moment, of course.A gammy arm means we Rosie is leading the workouts.But I was firmly of the opinion nothing and no one could ever stand in the way of world domination, until I tuned into Sunday night’s Diva On Lockdown and there was Gemma Collins trying to contort her mighty bulk into one of Joe’s squats while she bellowed: “I wonder how Joe Wicks would feelhe knew the GC was doing his workout ”Beaten, I’d imagine.He must never know.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.And her face is glued to the back of her head.So there will be hell to payit comes unstuck on The Real Marigold Hotel, where the only other one of the eight celebs who’s appeared looking as unearthly as Britt is former Dragons’ Den star Duncan Bannatyne, whose hair is now a “vibrant and colourful” shade of roast papaya orange. And will remain that way, until the monsoon breaks.It’s probably safe to say neither of them will be hanging around that long, though, or “retiring to India” any time soon.This is the fourth series of the BBC show and not one of the famous pensioners has given the place a second look yet.They have, however, all come home alive.So I wish the Beeb would count its lucky stars, cut the pretence, make Duncan pay for everyone’s holiday and let us all enjoy their discomfort, which is considerable and very entertaining.During the first episode: John “Nasty Nick” Altman proved as supple as Tower Bridge at his first ever yoga lesson.Paul Chuckle remained confined to barracks with the trots.Henry “Blowers” Blofeld rejected insect repellent on the grounds that: “Mosquitoes get p***edthey bite me.”And actress Susie Blake certainly didn’t hold back when the local foot doctor told her: “You have some unwanted growths.”“Yes, I have haemorrhoids.”Susie, too much inflammation.Jamie Redknapp: “We always used to turn up late but somehow we’d make it in time.Martin Keown: “Vieira was the best I ever played with. But Henry was a great player, so don’t make me choose between them.”Paul Merson: “The secret to working hard is to work hard.”ON one particularly fraught episode of her Channel  show, last week, Steph McGovern was forced to let a wasp out of her living room window, live on air.Probably halving her audience in the process.A day later it was announced the show itself was being released back into the wild, or as they put it “taking a break”.Credit for this development was being given to Steph’s long-suffering neighbours, who’d objected to the disruption the production had caused and may yet get a Bafta fellowship for their intervention.Truth be told, though, Steph’s “power hour of positivity” was more likely killed by worthiness, lack of content, technical issues and the host herself, who’s a rotten interviewer, kills every good joke stone dead, has the same set response to everythingand a terrible habit of asking exactly the wrong question.“Martin , what are you doing with all that toilet paper ” “Errr . . . ”There’s talk of a brave new dawn, in a shiny Leeds studio, later this year and when I last checked, author Marian Keyes was giving some pointed advice on how to become a good novelist: “Your first efforts will be woefully appalling. It’s like anything in le you want to be good at. Keep showing up.”Steph. Don’t.MORE now from Russell Grant’s “uncannily accurate”  predictions in December’s Mirror.“Scorpio — travel will be a great source of joy for you in April.”Yeah, April. How’d that work out for you Netflix thriller series Fauda. Channel ’s SAS: Who Dares Wins . Episode two of BBC’s Jewel Of Arabia .BBC repeating Bob Monkhouse: The Last Stand.And BBC Breakfast discovering that not only is he a war hero and charity giant, he’s a former Blankety Blank contestant as well.Cometh the hour, cometh Colonel Tom.Craig: “Arm.”Bradley Walsh: “What vowel precedes the name of more than ten dferent Apple products ”Becky: “C.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which word used to describe horses of a reddish brown colour is also a type of window ”Paul: “Velux.”RE: The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “The name of what flightless bird is slang for someone who refuses to face facts ”Becky: “Kiwi.”You mock, but I shouted: “Diane Abbott.”Table, restaurant, postcode, country, Commonwealth of Nations and beyond that, his own gravitational field.Dumbest question was obviously: “Would you like dessert ”CHANNEL ’s When Will Lockdown End  The highlights.Professor Hugh Montgomery: “I don’t know.”Professor Graham Medley: “Anyone who tells you they know is lying.”Professor Peter Horby: “We just don’t know.”So in conclusion, try asking Russell Grant.RANDOM irritations: Have I Got News For You echoing to nothing but the sound of its own self-satisfied laughter.ITV numbskulls destroying Van Der Valk’s famous theme tune.Toxic hypocrite Frankie Boyle biting the Press hand that’s fed him far too well, by the looks of things.BBC’s Panorama failing to reveal every single interviewee on Has The Government Failed The NHS  was a left-wing activist.And ITV’s Joel Dommett making we Hannah the co-host of his Home Alone show.Which is a bit like Linda McCartney sharing lead vocals with Ringo. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: social distancing lockdown workplace schools
story: RADICAL measures to prevent the spread of coronavirus in workplaces will be in place for up to a year, The Sun has been told.Screens between desks, staff sitting back-to-back and a ban on hot desking and sharing of equipment are among moves employers must introduce when lockdown is lted.The new measures — proposed in draft documents on ato workplaces — also require staggered sht times to avoid crowding on public transport.Handwashing kit must be at entry and exit points, with regular cleaning of worktops. Yellow and black tape will tell people where to stand in lts.One-way systems will be the norm in offices and on train s and at bus stops.Face-to-face meetings will only be able to go aheadabsolutely necessary and be time-limited.Employees will even be told not to share stationary such as pens.The message to employers is to allow their staff to work from homethey’re not needed in the workplace.It means home-working will likely become the default for millions of Brits for the foreseeable future.But employers will have to monitor the well-being of staff working from home by keeping in touch to ask about their welfare, physical health and personal security.The Government has told industry groups the new measures will have to be in place for between six and  months.They were told there will be a “gradual winding down” after the winter, The Sun has learnt.It is understood the y timeframe has been influenced by growing fears among the Government’s medical advisers that the coronavirus is seasonal.An industry source said: “If it survives the winter, these measures will have to be in place longer.”But one positive industry bosses are drawing from the new measures is the impact it will have on dampening traditional flu.The draft papers cover seven dferent settings: offices, hotel and restaurants, shops, factories, outdoor workplaces and those who work in vehicles and other people’s homes.Staggered sht times, less sharing of equipment and continued maximisation of home working are among a number of ideas listed as part of a draft government strategy to help businesses prepare for ato work.Increased hygiene procedures and the installation of protective screens are also included in the plan.Efforts to avoid employees working face-to-face will see them working side by side or facing away from each other, according to the plans leaked to Buzzfeed News.There will be limits on the number of people in stores so Brits will be asked to shop alone to enable shops to be allowed to open and kick-start the economy.The advice for reopening non-essential shops such as clothes stores will be similar to the supermarket rules.Tape setting out two metre distances will have to be put on shop floors, and Brits will need to queue outside.Many shops will go cashless to stop the spread of the virus through money.In cities like London, maintaining the two-metre rule would make it impossible for workplaces to operate anywhere near full capacity.Platforms and bus stops will contain two metre markers to maintain social distancing and one-way systems will be in place.A complex blueprint for schools to open in waves of dferent age groups is being planned.Reopening primary schools is a priority for the Government in order to minimise the threat to early years development and help parentsto work. But Year  pupils will be first backthey are forced to stagger the reopening dates as they are at the most crucial stage of their learning.PM Boris Johnson wants the first schools to reopen on June .Year  and  pupils are expected to be the first wave of secondary schools to open.No firm date has been set for reopening workplaces but The Sun revealed last week that May  has been pencilled in as a target date as long as the Government’s five tests for lting the lockdown measures are met by then.Mr Johnson will publish a “roadmap” strategy on Sunday, detailing exactly how restrictions will be eased in order for Brits to safelyto work.Defence Secretary Ben Wallace said measures such as shields, masks and limiting the amount of contact time with colleagues could be alternative approaches taken by employers.But the draft guidance did not contain details about what personal protective equipment staff should wear when theyto work.The Trades Union Congress refused to support the plans as they stand, saying they “fall far short of giving any guarantees to workers about their health and safety”.Ministers confirmed that the Government has started stockpiling face masks for public use.Scotland boss Nicola Sturgeon revealed she shares Boris Johnsons hopes of being able to start easing the coronavirus lockdown towards the end of May.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government fund zoos coronanoavirus
story: A GOVERNMENT fund of £million has been set up to help zoos and aquariums care for animals in the pandemic.The attractions have lost visitor income but still face costs of feeding, heating and security of their animals.The Department for Environment, Food  Rural Affairsalso plans to continue working with some of the largest zoos to discuss longer term concerns.Animal Welfare minister Lord Goldsmith said: “Zoos are facing real pressure and we have made support available, including business rates relief and the business interruption loan scheme.“This new Zoo Support Fund is designed to help those that need support to maintain the welfare of the animals.”Inidual grants of up to £, will be available for English sites covered by the Zoo Licensing Act.Steve Barclay, Chief Secretary to the Treasury, said: “Zoos don’t just provide a family day out but are vital for education, species protection and conservation.”Dr Madelon Willemsen, chief of the British and Irish Association of Zoos and Aquariums , said zoos and aquariums had gone to extraordinary s to cope with the pandemic while looking after animals despite the lack of income.“We are pleased to have worked with Defra in shaping this much needed crisis support for zoos and aquariums.“We continue to work to ensure those most in need have access to this and other forms of support.”Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun concerts key workers register
story: OUR army of key workers is heroically keeping the country running during this crisis.They have put their lives on the line to make sure the nation is safe. Now we will show our gratitude.The Sun has teamed up with Virgin Radio to host the Big Thank You Tour, a three-night UK arena extravaganza that will feature top music acts.And we are giving away , tickets to key workers — from NHS staff to carers, teachers, transport staff and shop assistants — who will be our guests of honour.The first concert will be held at Wembley SSE Arena on October .It will also incorporate our annual Who Cares Wins Awards — paying tribute to NHS staff, ­volunteers and charities who have touched, and saved, lives.Nominations will open next week.The tour will continue to Manchester Arena on October  and then Glasgow’s SSE Hydro on November .The Sun editor-in-chief Victoria Newton said: “The Sun’s Who Cares Wins Awards recognise the hard work, dedication and sheer brilliance of our NHS staff, from porters to nurses to surgeons.“This year, with so many heroic stories em­erging from the Covid- emergency, the Awards will be bigger than ever, and on a bigger stage than ever. title: healthy over 70s to be freed from strict lockdown
story: OVER-s should be able to self-select whether they are vulnerable or not once the lockdown is eased, ministers have said.It follows criticism that using age-based criteria to lt restrictions would lead to social unrest.About . million clinically vulnerable people have been told they must stay in lockdown for at least  weeks, with some ministers saying they might need to remain at home until there is a vaccine, which could take a year or more.They include people aged  or older regardless of medical conditions and those under  with an underlying health condition.As the government reviews its lockdown policy, British Medical Association and the Royal College of GPs said a wholesale lockdown of the elderly was discriminatory and unacceptable.Former minister Baroness Ros Altmann, , said Britain faces social unrestthe over-s are forced to live in a longer lockdown than younger generations.The Conservative peer said many older people would risk going to prison rather than being forced to isolate at home.Charity Director at Age UK Caroline Abrahams also spoke out against blanket policies based on age.Comedian Sir Michael Palin, , agreed in a separate interview that age restrictions would be very dficult and very wrong and very unfair.Amid the criticism, a minister close to the discussions concerning elderly and vulnerable people told thethe over-s will self-select whether they are vulnerable or not.They told the newspaper: The all over-s grouping is going to morph. There is a big dference between the . million shielded people, known as extremely critically vulnerable, who have been sent a letter advising them to shield for  weeks, vulnerable people with pre-existing health conditions of any age, and healthy over-s.This needs to be made clearer – you cant just have a blanket over-s group. Thats unsustainable. Its not a static group.The minister added: There arent enough supermarket delivery slots to cater for that amount of people.What we are going to see is more self-selection and personal responsibility.People will self-select whether they are vulnerable or not. The over-s are a very sensible group – by and large, they knowthey should be staying indoors or not.Meanwhile Tory Sir Graham Brady said on Monday night: We have today the most healthiest, active elderly generation of all time and it would be tragicGovernment threatened this by trying to extend a so-called lockdown for those judged to be most at risk based on age.Why dont we just give them the best information and advice and let them limit their risk themselves In the original Government guidance, anyone over , regardless of their state of health, was advised to be particularly stringent in following social distancing measures.But on May , that was withdrawn and replaced with new advice which listed all over-s as clinically vulnerable.Amid confusion over the guidelines, Health Secretary Matt Hancock tweeted: The clinically vulnerable, who are advised to stay in lockdown for  weeks, emphatically DO NOT include all over-s.The Department of Health and Social Care confirmed over s are not included in the most at risk group , who have been told to isolate for  weeks.On Monday, the Prime Ministers official spokesman said: Over-s are classed as being in the clinically vulnerable group – they are not necessarily in the clinically extremely vulnerable group, which are those people who are shielding.Therefore the advice to them is to take particular care to minimise contact with others outside their household.Asked whether the over-s would have dferent rules from other sections of the population, the spokesman added: We know that, as you get older, there is a higher risk of coronavirus having a more serious impact. Complications and deaths are more common in the elderly, even those without pre-existing conditions.But as we look forward it is perfectly reasonable that we will look at how guidance will apply for dferent age bands, and we will continue to be guided by the science.The UK coronavirus death toll hit , on Monday as another  patients died in the lowest rise in more than a month.The last time the UK recorded such a low  hour fatality rate was almost five weeks ago on March  when  deaths were reported.However there is often a drop in Mondays figures due to a lag in reporting over the weekend with Tuesdays number likely to be higher.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
