title: coronavirus-tests-key-workers-families-now-eligible---book-one
story: About  million key workers - and members of their household - can now book a swab test online via the governmentrsquos website from Friday , with testing having previously only been available to health workers.Who is eligible for the test Testing has now been extended to all key workers in England with symptoms, and members of the same household who have symptoms.The move marks a huge expansion of the people eligible for testing as the government moves towards its target of , daily tests by the end of April.It also means key workers can find out whether they have coronavirus, enabling them toto workthey test negative.Health Secretary Matt Hancock announced the news at the daily Downing Street press conference on Thursday , stating: ldquoWe can make it easier, faster and simpler for any essential worker in England who needs a test to get a test.ldquoAny essential workers who need a test will be able to book an appointment on gov.uk themselves directly.ldquoThis applies for people in essential workersrsquo households too, who need a test.ldquoItrsquos all part of getting Britain back on her feet.Who is classed as a key worker This is who is classed as a key worker, according to the government:- NHS and social care staff, including:- doctors, nurses, midwives, paramedics, social workers, care workers, and other frontline health and- social care staff including volunteers- the support and specialist staff required to maintain the UKrsquos health and social care sector- those working as part of the health and social care supply chain, including producers and distributors of medicines, and medical and personal protective equipment- Essential public services staff, including:- prisons, probation, courts and tribunals staff, judiciary- religious staff- charities and workers delivering critical frontline services- those responsible for the management of the deceased- journalists and broadcasters covering coronavirus or providing public service broadcasting- Public safety and national security staff, including:- police and support staff- Ministry of Defence civilians, contractors and armed forces personnel - fire and rescue service employees ,- National Crime Agency staff, those maintaining border security, prison and probation staff and other national security roles, including those overseas- Transport workers, including:- those who keep the air, water, road and rail passenger and freight transport modes operating during the coronavirus response- those working on transport systems through which supply chains pass- Education and childcare workers, including:- support and teaching staff- social workers- specialist education professionals- Critical personnel in the production and distribution of food, drink and essential goods, including:- those involved in food production, processing, distribution, sale and delivery- those critical to the provision of other essential goods, such as medical supply chain and distribution workers, including veterinary medicine- workers critical to the continuity of essential movement of goods- Local and national government staff critical to the effective delivery of the coronavirus response, or delivering essential public services, such as the payment of benefits- Public and environmental health staff, including in government agencies and armrsquosbodies- Frontline local authority staff, including those working with vulnerable children and adults, with victims of domestic abuse, and with the homeless and rough sleepers- Utilities, communication and financial services staff, including:- staff needed for essential financial services provision - building societies and financial market infrastructure- the oil, gas, electricity and water sectors - information technology and data infrastructure sector and primary industry supplies to continue during the coronavirus response- essential staff working in the civil nuclear, chemicals, telecommunications , postal services and delivery, payments providers and waste disposal sectorsWhat does the test involve The test involves taking a swab from the nose and the back of the throat, which can be done by the person themselves, or by someone .Testing is most effective within three days of symptoms developing.How can I book a test Key workers who are self-isolating can book a test directly.There is the option to select a regional test site drive-through appointment, or home test kit.Home test kit availability will initially be limited but more will become available, but there is good availability of regional test sites, so the government advises selecting this optionyou can.Alternatively, key workers can book a test through their employer.Employers can refer key workers who are self-isolating, either because they or members of their household have coronavirus symptoms, for testing.The employer referral portal is a secure for employers to use to upload the full list of names and contact details of self-isolating key workers.If referred through this portal, key workers will receive a text message with a unique invitation code to book a test for themselves,they are symptomatic, or their symptomatic household members at a regional testing site.To obtain a login, employers of essential workers should email portalservicedesk@dhsc.gov.uk with two email addresses that will primarily be used to load essential worker contact details.Once employer details have been veried, two login credentials will be issued for the employer referral portal.

title: inspired-irene-knits-charity
story: Irene, who lives in Haddington, has spent her time in lockdown knitting twiddle muffs and aims to produce  to donate to AlzheimerScotland.The colourful muffs provide people with restless hands a distraction and can be a comfort and distraction for some.Irene, , first began producing them six months ago and has used her time at home to challenge herself with her new target.And she has launched a JustGiving page for people to support her efforts and donate to AlzheimerScotland at the same time.She said: "Like so many elderly and vulnerable people, Irsquove found the recentCoronavirus lockdown situation dficult to adjust to in numerous ways."Luckily for me, whilst nowadays Irsquom a bitunsteady on my feet, Irsquom still very keen and pretty capable of doing all sortsof crafts and so have been filling the many hours, days and weeks of socialisolation by knitting twiddle muffs."There are actually several advantages to knitting twiddle muffs. Of course, thefirst and most important benefit is to the recipients ... people with dementiaoften have restless hands and like to have something to keep their handsoccupied."A twiddle muff provides awonderful source of visual, tactile and sensory stimulation, and keeps handssnug and warm at the same time."But Irsquovefound there are also benefits for me too ndash not only is knitting keeping mephysically and mentally occupied, itrsquos also making a great dent in my enormousstock of gorgeous textured and coloured wool that Irsquove been buying and hoardingfor years ... one of my guilty pleasures!"So far Irene, who lives in Monk Muir Park, has doubled her target of pound donations on her JustGiving page which stands at pound,.She said: "WatchingCaptain Tomrsquos recent endeavours to raise such an awesome amount for the NHS hasbeen an inspiration to us all."Irene is asking everyone to support her as she carries on knitting by donating to the charity.She said: "Irsquom now delighted to be donating all the twiddle muffs Irsquom knitting toAlzheimer Scotland for distribution to those in need and Irsquove set myself atarget of knitting a total of muffs."To help motivate me Irsquom hoping that all you generous people mighthelp me raise funds for Alzheimer Scotland, which is Scotlandrsquos nationaldementia charity, whose aim is to make sure that nobody faces dementiaalone."They provide support andinformation to people with dementia, their carers and families, includingproviding a  hour freephone Dementia Helpline."Alzheimer Scotland campaigns for the rightsof people with dementia and funds vital dementia research. Please donate what you can toinspire me to keep these knitting needles clacking."To donate go to bit.ly aCOrO

title: greggs-reveal-plan-reopen-stores-across-country
story: The Newcastle-based bakery chain said it was looking to open a small number of stores to trial how it would reopen more than , stores across the UK.The full details of how the trial will operate have not been released.Due to currentcoronaviruslockdown rules, it remainshighly likely that Greggs wouldoperate a takeaway service only with a limited number of staff working ateach store.Its understood that alimited number of stores could open by May , as part of a staggered plan to reopen fully once restrictions are lted.A spokesperson for Greggssaid on Sunday night : "We want to play our part in getting the nation back up and running again so we are planning to conduct a limited trial with volunteers to explore how we can reopen our shops with new measures in place that keep our colleagues and customers as safe as we can when we re-open at scale."McDonalds in talks to reopen storesIt comes after McDonalds said they were in talks about opening its , restaurants across the UK, according to reports.The burger chain could open for drive-thru and delivery orders as early as mid-May, the Irish Farmers Journal said.A spokesperson for McDonalds said: "Of course we are thinking about re-opening and having those conversations ndash but its unclear when that will be."

title: burger-king-greggs-kfc-nandos-mcdonalds-preparing-reopen-uk-stores
story: As of yesterday - heres what we know so far.GreggsGreggshaveconfirmed it islooking to reopen with a number of stores expected to reopen their doorsasearly as next week.The bakery chain said it was looking to open a small number of stores to trial how it would reopen more than , stores across the UK.Although the full details of how the trial will operate have not been released, it is believed a number ofNewcastlestores will be among the first to welcome customers back.But due to currentcoronaviruslockdown rules, it remainshighly likely that Greggs wouldoperate a takeaway service only with a limited number of staff working ateach store.Its understood that alimited number of stores could open by May , as part of a staggered plan to reopen fully once restrictions are lted.A spokesperson for Greggssaid on Sunday, April : "We want to play our part in getting the nation back up and running again so we are planning to conduct a limited trial with volunteers to explore how we can reopen our shops with new measures in place that keep our colleagues and customers as safe as we can when we re-open at scale."McDonaldsNo confirmed date has been revealed as to when McDonalds will , but work is going on behind the scenes to prepare for a small-but-steadyacross the country.Paul Pomroy, McDonaldrsquos CEO UK and Ireland said on Tuesday, April :"In March, we took the decision to temporarily close our restaurants in the UK and Ireland for the safety of our people and customers. Recently, we began working through a potential and limited reopening."We have been listening to our employees and customers as well as engaging with government and trade bodies to help ensure we do this responsibly, when the time is right."Restarting our business is not an easy task even when reopening in a limited capacity. We have set ourselves some key criteria for reopening, all of which take time ndash first and foremost ensuring the wellbeing of our people and creating the right environment for them toto work secondly ensuring we have enough supply of fresh produce and finally working in-step with government guidelines to ensure the safety of our customers."This week we are carrying out some operational tests to explore what our reopening might look like the restaurant where these tests take place will remain closed to the public."These tests will include exploring social distancing measures for our crew, PPE options and opening in a limited capacity."For now we remain closed, and will only reopen when we are absolutely confident we can have the right measures in place to ensure everyonersquos wellbeing.Burger KingBurger King has revealed it will open  more restaurants across the country.The move comes after the recentre-opening of six branches - all offering alimited menu to customers Dundee and Merton in London - however theexact locations have not beenconfirmed.NandosNandorsquos has said it is reopening six of its UK restaurants for delivery from today .The peri-peri chicken chain said it will reopen the kitchens of four restaurants in London and two in Manchester to offer a delivery service through Deliveroo.It comes after Nandorsquos restarted cooking at these sites last week to serve food for NHS workers and charities.The restaurant chain said it will offer deliveries from its Camberwell, Canary Jubilee, Clink Street and Gloucester Road sites in London.It will also serve customers in Manchester from its Fallowfield and Printworks locations.Nandorsquos said it will offer a reduced delivery menu from these sites, but will not be offering eat-in or collection services.In a statement, Nandorsquos said: ldquoThe menu will be reduced to help the team maintain social distance in the kitchen and food prep areas, but never fear as the majority of Nandorsquos favourites such as peri-peri chicken wings, halloumi and peri chips will now be available to enjoy at home.ldquoEach Nandorsquos restaurant has been working under Public Health England guidelines for the past week on top of their existing health and safety procedures.ldquoEvery member of the team has been washing their hands more frequently while maintaining social distance during shts.ldquoAfter a successful trial re-opening serving meals to local good causes, they are now upping production to serve the public.The company stressed that this is the ldquofirst phase of its reopening plans but more restaurants could follow suit and open for deliveriesit is successful.Nandorsquos said that each restaurant will also continue to cook meals every sht for local charities and NHS workers.KFCKFC is set to reopen moreof its branches across the country after bringing in a new set of rules to keep staff and customers safe.The fast-foodretailer began closing its stores on March  following the governments decision to place the UK on lockdown.At that time, KFC said that it wanted to "protect the wellbeing and safety" of staff and customers, and confirmed that the temporary closures would be "until further notice."It was then revealed earlier this month that eleven stores would reopen as part of an initial phase, including two sites in Manchester.The chain is however offering a "limited menu" to customers and service is delivery-only, available through Deliveroo, Just Eat and Uber Eats for those who live near one of the restaurants.In a statement about reopening stores, KFC title: royal-mail-stop-saturday-letter-deliveries-due-coronavirus-pandemic
story: It said it will continue to provide its letter delivery service from Monday to Friday as normal and said customers ldquoshould continue to post both letters and parcels as usual on Saturday.Royal Mail will continue to collect all mail from businesses, post offices and post boxes, it said.When will Saturday deliveries temporarily stop The will be halted from this weekend .What have Royal Mail said Shane OrsquoRiordain, managing director of marketing, regulation and corporate affairs at Royal Mail, said: ldquoOur postmen and postwomen are working very hard across the UK in challenging conditions.ldquoAs we said at the start of the coronavirus crisis, there will be some disruption to services.ldquoWe understand the importance of the postal service in keeping the UK connected at this time.ldquoWe have also listened to our hard-working colleagues who have asked us to ease the additional burden on thempossible. As a result, we are making some temporary changes to postal services.Royal Mail said it has been in dialogue with the Government and regulator Ofcom throughout the crisis and will keep the temporary change to postal arrangements under review.Reaction to the moveThe decision was criticised by the Communication Workersrsquo Union , which represents postal workers.A CWU spokesman said: ldquoWe will be seeking urgent discussions with the Government on this issue.ldquoThe reduction of the Universal Service Obligation was a key factor in our live national strike ballot.ldquoThe last thing we want to do is call strike action at this point but we will not sit back and see our membersrsquo jobs put at threat and the service to the public worsened.Last month the union called for householdsrsquo deliveries to be cut to three days a week due to coronavirus.

title: teachers-well-placed-assess-students-grades
story: The Scottish Qualications Authorityhas revealed how it aims to determine the  exam results for students due to sit them, following the suspension of normal examinations due to Covid-.And Lesley Brown, the councilrsquos chief operating officer for education, said schools were prepared to provide the evidence needed and review the results using their professional judgement.She said: ldquoWe know that the closure of schools and the cancellation of exams has caused anxiety and uncertainty for our pupils and their families. Irsquom pleased that the SQA has now confirmed its approach, and I am especially pleased to see recognition that teachers and schools are best-placed to provide a judgement on pupilsrsquo achievements.ldquoOur schools regularly monitor and track pupilsrsquo progress throughout the academic year as part of our approaches to ensuring high-quality learning, teaching and assessment. Teachersrsquo professional judgement is at the heart of our approach in Scotland and our teachers are very well placed to provide the information required by SQA.ldquoWe are working with our headteachers and school teams to make sure that our approach across East Lothian is consistent, rigorous and accurately reflects pupilsrsquo achievements. Our teachers will estimate grades using all evidence available to them, with support from their subject faculties, wider school teams and from our central education team.The SQA says its approach to awarding grades is based on safe and secure certication following public health advice and maintaining the integrity and credibility of the qualications system.Schools and colleges will be asked to provide the SQA with estimates on pupilsrsquo achievements, grades, bands and rank based on their performance so far in subject activities.This will provide an overall judgement from those the SQA describes as ldquobest placed to do so, with submissions due by May .The SQA will then check and validate the estimates it receives and look at prior assessments undertaken by pupilsthey are available ndash for example, Higher results for an Advanced Higher pupil.The schoolsrsquo previous history in estimating attainment will be considered and SQA will hold Awarding Meetings with its subject experts.Results will be delivered to learners by August  and students are encouraged to register for MySQA to receive their results by text and or email.The appeals process will remain free for schools and colleges so they can advocate on their pupilsrsquo behalfthe results do not reflect the candidatersquos achievements.The SQA has an exams QA for parents and pupils on its website, www.sqa.org.uk

title: athelstaneford-primary-school-takes-talent-show-online

title: pubs-may-limit-drinkers-three-pints-lockdown-lifted
story: Heres what you need to know.What social distancing rules could pubs face When pubs reopen for business, patrons could be limited to three drinks each before being asked to head home, in order to free up space for others to visit, a government advisor has suggested.The strict rules would also include maintaining a social distance of two metres while inside, with landlords able to issue fines to those who flout the rules.The terms are outlined in a plan by economist and government advisor, Professor Eyal Winter, who said social distancing is the key to coming out of lockdown. He also argued that the public need to know what the government has planned in terms of a lockdown exit strategy.Speaking to , he said: ldquoPeople are starving for pubs. They are an important part of British culture.ldquoOne of the most important things is to have a programme, to say, lsquoIn two weeks we will do such and such.rsquoldquoYou need to make the rules crystal clear, and to explain to the public the rationale behind each one of them.When are pubs likely to reopen Professor Winter estimated that it will take ldquoa lot of time to move back to how le was in January , but was certain that the country ldquowill get there.The Mail Online has reported that a possible exit plan could see the UK come out of lockdown in phases. The public would allegedly be allowed back into outdoor spaces first, with pubs being the last to open, as the lockdown was lted.Cabinet Office minister, Michael Gove, confirmed that areas of hospitality will be among the last to see restrictions lted.When asked whether pubs would open ldquobefore winter, Mr Gove told Sky News: ldquoThe other inference that I draw from your question, which is that areas of hospitality will be among the last to exit the lockdown - yes, that is true.What about cinemas and theatres Professor Winter has also been advising ministers on how to go about lting lockdown, and said cinemas and theatres could also reopen, but must have half empty auditoriums.Every other seat would have to be unoccupied, but he said venues could make up for the loss of money by raising ticket prices.

title: neighbours-join-forces-ensure-memorable-80th-birthday
story: James Walker, known as Jim, lives on St Margarets Road with we Valerie and celebrated his big day on Monday.Initial plans were for his daughter Morag to travel from Ireland, where she currently stays with her partner and family, and his two sons Alastair and Graeme to visit from Staffordshire and Edinburgh respectively.However, the coronavirus lockdown changed this, and meant that his family were not able to be by his side.Morag contacted Jim and Valrsquos lsquolockdown street linkrsquo for the area ndash put in place by the townrsquos resilience team ndash to askanyone could make a cake for her dadrsquos birthday.Morag said: ldquoI knew the street link lady is an active member of the community so would knowanyone was able to help.The plan snowballed from a kind neighbour making a chocolate cake to other neighbours gathering in front of Jim and Valeriersquos house to sing a socially distanced lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo.When he heard his doorbell ring, Jim was amazed to find the chocolate cake at the front door.Neighbours from nearby Marmion Road and St Margarets Road struck up a chorus of lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo, while Jim waved from the doorstep.He then walked to the pavement to thank everyone.ldquoItrsquos a lovely day for us to eat cake and have a cup of tea in the garden, said we Valerie.Morag said: ldquoMy dad was a bit taken aback but really appreciated the surprise. title: bridges-project-continues-vital-work-lockdown
story: Regular face-to-face sessions and group activities at the Bridges Project on Bogpark Road have been replaced with phone calls, text messages, video calls and digital work as the lockdown becomes challenging for some.Despite the dficult times as a result of the pandemic, staff have discovered ldquopositive elements of lsquoremotersquo working with young people in East Lothian and Midlothian. They have now been working from home for more than a month and have continued to support vulnerable and disadvantaged young people with ious issues which has brought about some ldquounexpected outcomes.Lynne Anderson, transitions development worker, has noticed that she is able to use her time more wisely by phoning her clients instead of driving up to an hour each way to visit them at their homes.She said: ldquoWe can use this situation to learn how things work dferently. There are opportunities to continue doing some of the activities we are doing remotely when weto normal.She is one of several staff members who have had to change the way they give support over the past weeks but it still focuses on many of the same issues. They provide help with filling out job and college applications, and provide young people with emotional support and tutoring. The response has also generally been very positive, with staff members reporting engagement levels of up to  per cent from their clients.Natasha McInninie, transitions service co-ordinator, said: ldquoI am surprised by how resilient young people are. I thought we would lose a lot of young people through this situation. However, it has actually made them engage more.Emma Scarclfe, acting chief executive, is also very pleased by how both Bridges Project staff and the young people they work with have responded to the current crisis.She said: ldquoBridges Project has adapted quickly to the unexpected situation around Covid-. Engagement continues to be extremely high and the commitment and dedication from staff to change their working practices so quickly to suit each inidual young person has been a complete triumph. Wersquore all very proud of the way young people have adapted and how resilient they are.However, there are also issues which have become ldquomagnied during the lockdown, for example, people who have dficult relationships with their family members struggle with being ldquolocked up together over such a long period. Others are affected by less income and need help with accessing food parcels, Universal Credit and other types of financial support.Many young people also need help to deal with the impact the Covid- crisis is having on their mental health. This is particularly the case for those who were already struggling with social anxiety or social isolation prior to the lockdown.Lynne said: ldquoIn the beginning, the young people thought it was fantastic. Now the reality of the lockdown is settling in and it is starting to become challenging.This trend has also been observed by personal development worker, Chris Nicol, who said: ldquoThe young people were dealing with it well during the first few weeks but have seen a downturn in their mood over the last two weeks. This is due to a combination of boredom and too much time to think but also not seeing their friends. They have realised how important those social anchors really are.He highlighted the importance of keeping young peoplersquos motivation and confidence up during these challenging times.He explained: ldquoI remind them that they need to focus on the fact that this will last for a relatively short period of their lives and things will go back to normal.Thank you for reading this story. title: family-wake-find-trapped-vandal-screws-gate-shut
story: Aislinn and Charles Balderston, of Clford Road, North Berwick, and their sons Frankie, , Arthur and Teddy, both , were trapped in their front garden when they tried to leave the property to take the twins to the GP surgery.ldquoWe were watching TV one night, said Mrs Balderston, ldquoAnd we heard this really funny noise, like a drill or something. Then something pinged off the sitting room window.ldquoI looked out but I couldnrsquot see anything so we went to bed and forgot about it.ldquoIn the morning we went to take the babies to the doctor for their MMR jags but couldnrsquot open the front gate.She added: ldquoWhen we went back through the house and round, we saw that the top of the gate had been broken off, then used to screw the gate shut.ldquoThe noise we heard had been an electric screwdriver.The family reported the incident to the police, and neighbours were informed via a WhatsApp online messaging group set up to support the community during Covid-.Mrs Balderston continued: ldquoWe wonderedsomeone was annoyed at us for leaving the house but we only go to the supermarket once a week.ldquoIt doesnrsquot look like an act of random vandalism ndash it was done by someone who really meant it.ldquoDeliberately screwing our gate shut when we are in the house with three children would not have had a great outcome had there been a fire and we needed to get out the front way.A police spokesperson said: ldquoAround .am on Monday, April , a report was made to officers about damage to a gate at an address on Clford Road, North Berwick. title: volunteers-dishing-hundreds-hot-meals

title: goblin-ha-inspires-author-release-first-fantasy-novel
story: Goblin Hall, described as ldquoa humour-laced fantasy adventure for all the family, marks the latest chapter in the ied career of Peter Kerr.Widely known for his Snowball Oranges and Bob Burns Investigates series, he has turned his hand to another genre, with a nod towards The Goblin Harsquo, a reputedly haunted chamber that lies beneath the ruins of Yester Castle, near Gford.He said: ldquoI actually wrote the story, I think, about  years ago.ldquoIt was when my first book, Snowball Oranges, was just coming out, after waiting about  years to get published.ldquoI had an agent in London at the time and she said the way I write is very visual and I should have a go at writing a film script.ldquoI had never even read one but took her at her word and looked at the layout and general routine for laying down film scripts.ldquoAs for the The Goblin Harsquo, I had been to the old castle, with one of my pals who lived in Gford, when we were both about  way back in the s.ldquoThe place itself was not much to see, except peeking into the underground chamber, which inspired me.ldquoIt was bloody frightening and a very spooky place ndash it stuck in my mind.It was only two years ago, when transferring stories to a new computer, that Peter revisited his original film script and set about creating the novel.The legend of the Goblin Harsquo states that Sir Hugo de Gfard, known as the Wizard of Yester, made a pact with the devil to raise a magical army, who he used to carry out his will.Peterrsquos new tale, which is available from Amazon, features an evil sorcerer called Zorn, who has lured two young children into his subterranean lair as bait to ensnare his arch rival, a wizard called Mungo.It is up to the lovable but dippy old wizard to help free the youngsters from Zornrsquos clutches.The author, of Haddingtonrsquos Chalybeate, said feedback about the story was ldquoquite encouraging.That came despite the -year-old making an interesting revelation to the Courier. He said: ldquoI honestly donrsquot think I have ever read a fantasy novel!ldquoThat same literary agent, when she was trying to get a publisher for Snowball Oranges, told me detective novels were always popular.ldquoIrsquove never read one of those either and she said, lsquowell,you write one it will be original, evenit is rubbishrsquo.ldquoThat was the same attitude I took towards writing the fantasy novel.ldquoThe reaction so far has been quite encouraging.Peter was in popular s jazz band the Clyde Valley Stompers, who charted with Peter and The Wolf and were supported by The Beatles before the Fab Four made it big.Later, Peter produced more than  albums ndash including the Royal Scots Dragoon Guardsrsquo international chart-topper Amazing Grace ndash the biggest-selling instrumental of all time with  million sales.Thank you for reading this story. title: leuchie-houses-work-lauded-scottish-parliament
story: Mr Gray put down a motion that highlighted Leuchiersquos scores in its latest Care Inspection report, which place it among the highest scoring services of its kind in Scotland.It added that the report ldquois further testimony to the ongoing commitment from everyone at Leuchie to providing a first-class service for people living with MS and other long-term conditions, and their families.The motion also thanked Leuchiersquos staff for their ldquovaluable contribution in responding to coronavirus, which has seen the respite centre adapt and become a temporary lsquostep downrsquo facility for NHS patients to help free up beds during the ongoing crisis.Mr Gray said: ldquoLeuchie Housersquos latest Care Inspectorate report was really outstanding and underlines the ongoing efforts that the staff and trustees have been making to further enhance the service they provide to guests and their families.ldquoIt is a unique and special national respite care facility and these latest scores place it among the very best in Scotland, so Irsquom pleased to be able to recognise and promote this success at Holyrood.ldquoThe motion also afforded an opportunity to highlight the way the team at Leuchie have adapted to support the NHS during the Covid- crisis.ldquoThey have responded very quickly to help relieve some of the pressure on our NHS and I thank all of the staff, trustees and volunteers for their dedication.Mark Bevan, Leuchie Housersquos chief executive, said: ldquoGood news is always welcome and particularly in these challenging times. It was great to read the inspectorrsquos report, which recognised the huge effort, kindness and skill of a very dedicated and expert team at Leuchie, who at the moment are making a massive contribution to the NHS effort to fight Covid-.ldquoLeuchie quickly re-provisioned in response to the virus and has been taking patients from hospital beds which are much needed by others. title: lockdown-birthday-proves-one-remember-neighbours-wave
story: Ian Millar has been recovering from heart bypass surgery at his home in Haddington and, under lockdown guidelines, has been staying in.However, daughter Susan was determined to make sure his landmark birthday did not go unmarked, and decorated his car with balloons and a poster asking passers-by to wave to her dad.And, last Friday, lots of families out for their daily walk stopped to do just that.Susan said: ldquoDad has not been able to get out of the house and is recovering from his operation so I wanted to surprise him. Lots of people waved to him through his window during the day and he really enjoyed it.Ian, who is originally from Linlithgow, moved to East Lothian with his we Jean more than  years ago, living in Auldhame and Seaclf before settling in North Berwick.A mechanic, Ian worked at Fowlerrsquos Garage and the Bass Rock Garage in the town, before starting East Lothian School of Motoring in .The couple had two children and, following the loss of Jean in  and retirement a year later, Ian moved to Haddington to be closer to daughter Susan.For his th birthday, Susan decorated the car in his driveway on Dobsonrsquos Walk, since they were unable to hold a party.Susan said: ldquoWe put a sign on his car saying, lsquoPlease give me a wave as Irsquom  today,rsquo and dad then spent the day being waved to by passers-by. He even had a visit from the police after a family member in the police in Edinburgh asked local officers to come around! Later on, he spent the evening on a video call with his children, four grandchildren and two great grandchildren.Thank you for reading this story. title: nisa-store-steps-donates-1-300-charities-vulnerable
story: Pinkie Farm Convenience Store, one of Nisarsquos independent outlets, has donated essentials to the vulnerable and families in the area who are struggling with financial hardship.Support from the store ndash led by managing director Dan Brown ndash has included a pound donation to East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes, pound to Resilient Musselburgh and a further pound to Pennypit Community Development Trust.East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes provide fresh produce boxes containing all the ingredients needed to prepare a full roast dinner to struggling families.The charityrsquos founder, Jane Russell, said the donation would provide  local families with their dinner boxes.She commented: ldquoI set up the project in December  to give out free fresh chicken dinner boxes to people financially struggling in East Lothian.ldquoThe idea was to create a box of fresh produce so they had everything to cook a Sunday roast chicken dinner, and so the families could all sit together and enjoy a healthy meal.ldquoWe have helped over  families so far. The reason I set it up was because I myself have been in that position and, with three kids, financially struggling is so hard, decidingyou can afford food or gas.ldquoI wanted to make our project easy for people to ask for help without any forms to fill in or feel embarrassed.ldquoThe feedback and the support from the local community to help us is just amazing. The donation we received from Nisa will provide  families with our fresh chicken dinner boxes, which is just amazing.The donations were made via Nisarsquos lsquoMaking a Dference Locallyrsquo charity which raises funds in-store from the sale of Co-op and Heritage own brand products and has seen the Pinkie Farm Convenience Store donate almost pound, to local causes.The donations are just one of many ways in which the store is reaching out to support the local community, having recently launched new pound lsquoessentials kitsrsquo aimed at helping the most vulnerable people in the community and those who are self-isolating.Food kits have also been given to staff at Musselburgh Primary Health Care Centre and fresh produce contributed to East Lothian Foodbank, amongst other initiatives to help those most in need.Thank you for reading this story. title: delivering-hope-cheer-supplies-couriers-community
story: Couriers are being delivered to  North Berwick residents who are unable to leave their homes due to coronavirus shielding thanks to a new support fund to help people in the town.While in Haddington, the townrsquos Rotary Club this week purchased  copies to deliver to residents in lockdown in their town.North Berwick Community Council chairman Judy Lockhart said the initiative was aimed, primarily, at residents who did not have access to the internet but wanted to find out what was happening in the area and to get vital information about how to get help and support.Copies of the paper are delivered by North Berwick Community Emergency Resilience Group volunteers to housing for older people, care homes, the day centre and people who were not able to get out of their homes.ldquoWe want to ensure that everyone knows whatrsquos going on and how to get help and support at a very dficult time, said Judy.ldquoThe Courier is a leline. We know local newsagents deliver to many people, but this short-term scheme will ensure that people who donrsquot get a delivery or who canrsquot afford a Courier are kept in touch. It is also important to support the Courier during this periodwe are to see it survive. Newspapers are essential for local democracy and the Courier regularly reports on issues we discuss at the council.One of the volunteers who deliver the newspaper is Susan Taylor ndash in her beloved Dolly CV which goes by the name of Myrtille.Susan, whose day job is working for the Church of Scotland as an executive assistant, is one of the team of resilience group volunteers picking up prescriptions for residents.ldquoI volunteered because I really feel for those people in our community who are at risk and isolated due to the Covid- outbreak, she said. ldquoI have met some lovely people so far and am glad I am in a position to help.The project is paid for through the townrsquos Community Emergency Resilience Fund ndash which comprises public donations, funding from North Berwick Community Council and the North Berwick Trust.Rotary Haddington was always looking for ways to support its community, said club president Malcolm Collins.ldquoOur idea to bulk-buy and distribute copies of the Courier to the elderly and vulnerable originated from one of our members who was quick to realise that a signicant number of such people would soon begin to feel isolated and lose touch with what was happening locallythey were unable to get out and buy a copy, he added.ldquoAs well as providing local news, the initiative shown by the Courier by including pages of extra puzzles in the paper was also thought to be useful to help keep folk entertained during these dficult times.ldquoWe have now taken this idea forward and arranged to bulk-buy copies of the Courier each week in advance, have them delivered to a central hub and then arranged for them to be distributed to other locations where they can be made available to those in need e.g. Our Community Kitchen, those in care homes and other locations as they become known to us.Rotary Haddington members would ensure that the papers were delivered where they were needed, he added.Courier Editor Robbie Scott said: ldquoWersquore so grateful to these groups for supporting our communities during lockdown and the amazing work they do inspires us to produce the best papers that we can.ldquoFor them to also title: uk-lockdown-eased-schools-travel-sport
story: This will be a ldquomenu of options with the dates and times driven by the current state of the outbreak in the UK, he added.Ministers have faced continued questioning over the UKrsquos plan for lting its coronavirus lockdown, as European countries begin to ease their own restrictions.Italy and Spain are among those planning small steps to relax measures, while the Scottish and Welsh governments have set out dferent visions of how the current restrictions could be lted when the outbreak is under control.The next three-week review of the lockdown restrictions is due on Thursday, May .But how could the lockdown be lted across ious sectors  Heres a round-up of what you need to know.SchoolsUnder lockdown, schools and colleges have largely been closed, except for the children of essential workers, and it is thought this could be among the first restrictions to be eased.But Education Secretary Gavin Williamson previously said the Government had ldquono plans to open schools over the summer period, while Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said it would be ldquoinconceivable without some further measures in place.Head teachers have previously been advised to start making preparations on how schools could safely reopen, with the Association of School and College Leaderssuggesting a staggeredof pupils.ConstructionSome of Britainrsquos largest housebuilders ndash including Persimmon, Taylor Wimpey and Redrow ndash have already announced plans to reopen building sites in late April or early May.Under Government guidance, construction has been permittedin accordance with social distancing rules, but many companies halted work in response to the crisis.The Home Builders Federation said the restart is expected to be gradual, being dependent on how far supporting suppliers and services, such as building inspectors, mortgage lenders and conveyancers, can alsoto work.Activity will also be limited until the Government changes advice which effectively prohibits all but exceptional house moves.OfficesProperty services provider CBRE has drawn from its experiences in Asia to issue guidance to workplaces on how offices might approach re-opening in the future.It advises against a ldquofull throttleto work, with social-distancing measures needing to be reduced gradually and in line with public health guidance.It suggests businesses should establish internal taskforces to consider issues around access to PPE supplies, touchless technologies, temperature screening and reconfiguring work environments.Social gatheringsLimited social gatherings could be permitted in an easing of lockdown, but should be accompanied by extensive testing and contact tracing, one expert has suggested.Dr Joshua Moon, research fellow in sustainability research methods in the Science Policy Research Unitat the University of Sussex Business School, said the Government could adopt a ldquoslow release valve approach to the issue.He explained a phased approach might see certain sections of the population, for example healthy middle-aged people, given more freedoms initially, but he warned this risked the most vulnerable suffering the hardships of lockdown the longest.Dr Moon said family ldquoclusters could gradually be permitted to socialise, but could not make long journeys to do so, while most businesses remained shut.ldquoThe idea is that within those groups you can quite easily test, trace and isolate, he said, adding that it was harder to monitor for people moving around in public.HospitalitySector representative body UKHospitality has focused its energies on getting business support extended to places like bars and restaurants.A spokesman suggested that evenvenues were allowed to open with reduced capacity, businesses would still struggle financially.The All Party Parliamentary Group for Hospitality and Tourism has launched an urgent inquiry into how the sectors could reopen.This includes looking at operational challenges, reactivating supply chains, Government support and encouraging demand. A report is expected by mid-May.Pub chain Wetherspoonrsquos has said it plans to reopen its bars and hotels in June and said that due to it having larger than average pubs social distancing measures could be applied.RetailMinisters are thought to be considering allowing some non-essential businesses to open, such as garden centres and car showrooms, provided social-distancing could be maintained.Lobby group the British Retail Consortium has produced guidelines on how stores could prepare for the easing of restrictions.The guidance draws on lessons learned from supermarkets in recent weeks to ensure the re-opening of non-essential firms can be done safely.Advice coverslimiting entry and exit points, using floor markings to outline social distancing and keeping changing rooms closed.The guidance also suggests installing cleaning stations with hand sanitiser and disinfectant wipes at the front of stores.SportIt is understood Culture Secretary Olive Dowden has been working on a plan for major sports to be played behind closed doors when some social-distancing rules are eased.Weekly meetings are to be held between the Government, Public Health England and medical officials from sports bodies, with the issue due to be on the table when ministers review current measures next month.Key questions that need to be tackled include testing requirements, burdens on emergency services and the possible impact on fan behaviour ndash such as impromptu gatherings outside grounds.Sporting bodies are understood to be keen to resume full training safely as soon as possible.TravelLast week, low-cost European carrier Wizz Air announced plans to resume some flights from Luton Airport on May .Cabin crew will be required to wear masks and gloves on all flights and will distribute sanitising wipes for passengers, while new distancing measures will also be introduced during boarding.Mr Raab has indicated that officials are looking at possible checks at air and sea ports, with passengers arriving in the UK required to quarantine for  days.Meanwhile, the Rail, Maritime and Transportunion warned there was ldquozero chance of ramping up transport services soon, amid speculation of an increase on May  or May  when a new rail timetable is due.Last week, industry sources said no dates have yet been agreed or announced.

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience effort in Cockenzie and Port Seton has been helping launch a Fair Share hub at the Port Seton Centre this past week.The charity Fair Share delivers surplus food from supermarkets to the centre every Friday.The hub will cover the whole of East Lothian and support the centrersquos existing work to provide hot meals and food packs to families in need and children who would usually receive free school meals.Bryan Hickman, chairman of the local community council, which is leading the resilience effort, said: ldquoWe are still delivering food to those who need it but the Fair Share hub has been set up.ldquoWe receive food like coffee, cereal, milk and biscuits but this could change every week.ldquoItrsquos really good news that we have set this up as it will help us give other types of food. It will also help us financially because it is free.Meanwhile, the resilience effort is continuing to help those in need when requests come in, and currently has about  volunteers.A volunteer has also started offering a dog walking service.Contact detailsThose who require assistance can call the resilience emergency number on  . Updates are also posted on the Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council Twitter twitter CandPSCC and Facebook pages www.facebook Cockenzie-and-Port-Seton-Community-Council-.East SaltounHumbie, East and West Saltoun and BoltonFOUR volunteer groups are operating to help residents of neighbouring rural villages during the coronavirus pandemic.A resilience group, involving members of the Humbie, East and West Saltoun and Bolton Community Council, was previously formed.Alastair Beck, community council treasurer, said: ldquoVolunteers in the four village groups are supporting residents in their communities.ldquoAnyone in need of support, whether for shopping, pharmacy runs, etc, or who would just like someone to talk to should make contact with their village coordinator.Contact detailsPeople in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by email shenajamieson@aol.East Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahoo.In West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmail.Finally, in Humbie, people are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailMacmerryMacmerry and GladsmuirA LEAFLET drop to all residents across Macmerry and Gladsmuir last week led to the numbers of calls dealt with by the resilience team double.The team also offer a hot food service, and requests for this have quadrupled in the past week from two to eight.Stevie Sutherland, one of the resilience co-ordinators, said: ldquoI definitely envisage this increasing as it develops.ldquoSome might use it for a couple of days, some might use it for a couple of months.ldquoMaybe we can give a bit more help, askingthere is anything  they need.ldquoNeighbours are also looking after one another and they seem to be managing themselves.ldquoI think most people receiving meals are over .ldquoAll that happens is they are getting one hot meal per day. They might not be getting anything  but itrsquos just making sure they are getting at least one every day.Children have also been receiving wool in craft packs and are encouraged to make colourful pom poms, and hang them from their gates or a nearby lamppost.Stevie said: ldquoThe pom poms will start gathering pace now. Wersquove also put some posts up about it on social media. ldquoHopefully we are going to be inundated with them.ldquoWe want both villages to be decorated with as much colour as possible, in support of frontline workers.Volunteers at the resilience group are continuing to help with prescription and shopping collections.Stevie added: ldquoItrsquos just about getting that help out there.Contact detailsMore information is available on the resilience grouprsquos Facebook and Twitter pages, at facebook groups   and twitter MacmerryTeamMusselburghMusselburghAN AVERAGE of  lunch packs have been prepared and distributed weekly, as well as a daily distribution of emergency food packs by the growing army of  volunteers who make up the Resilient Musselburgh team.And about  free soup and sandwich lunches have been distributed to Whitecraig residents each week, Monday to Friday, by Graham Blaikie, who runs Mercat Grill, helped by Mrs Bennett.The team is also now providing freshly cooked meals.Community Councillor Margaret Stewart explained: ldquoHickory Foods, based at Eskmills, have offered us their kitchen facilities and staff for free to prepare freshly cooked meals which are delivered into the community.ldquoThe staff at the base identy, from referral forms, those who they feel would be most in need and make contact to offer this food support.ldquoWe are trialling this on a two-week basis, where a three-course freshly prepared meal is delivered to those identied for seven days a week.ldquoThis week  meals will have been delivered. This support is specically targeted at vulnerable members of the community, where it is felt that they would benefit from a nutritious meal. All meals are packaged and labelled with instructions for heating.ldquoThis will be reviewed after the first two weeks. However, we have been seeking feedback and, so far, it has been exceptional, with many comments of appreciation and thanks.She added: ldquoWe are still looking to build on our pool of volunteers to ensure sustainability, so anyone who would be interested in supporting us can register via eastlothian.gov.uk info  musselburgh_area_partner ship  resilient_musselburgh.As well as the pound, awarded to the Musselburgh Area Partnership to support the whole community response, Resilient Musselburgh has received a number of funding donations from community groups and organisations.Volunteers have been delivering information leaflets to households in targeted areas and Councillor Andy Forrest arranged for Musselburgh Post Office to deliver leaflets to all other locations.Contact detailsThe Resilient Musselburgh dedicated support number is  .PrestonpansPrestonpansDEMAND for assistance from the Prestonpans resilience team increased last week, reflecting both the pressure families are under going into week five of the lockdown, and a wider awareness of the support available to local people.Allan Sneddon, who is leading the Prestonpans resilience effort, said: ldquoOur volunteers have started providing a dog walking service for several people who are shielding, and this is being co-ordinated on our team leadersrsquo WhatsApp group. This seems to be working very well.ldquoThe three local Scotmid stores in Prestonpans are offering a free home delivery service and, with the help of our resilience volunteersrsquo leaflets advertising the service, have been delivering throughout the town. We are also helping to deliver shopping orders.The Pantry, operating from the Pennypit, also saw demand for meals increase in week four, with  meals delivered to households throughout the town.The Pantry is receiving lots of practical support in the form of food donations from local stores in the area, and financial donations have been given by the Prestonpans and Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Councils, PSG Area Partnership, Prestonpans British Legion, Prestonpans Labour Club and Longniddry Villa FC.Prestonpans Community Council have also set aside funds to help households who are struggling to make ends meet and the Corra Foundation, Scottish Governmentrsquos Food Fund, the Prestonpans British Legion and RBL Scotland Pipe Band have made signicant donations to this fund.Contact detailsIf anyone needs help, they should telephone   or email prestonpansresilience@gmailIF YOUR resilience group would like to purchase copies of the Courier to deliver to residents who are shielding and unable to leave their homes then please email Courier Editor Robbie Scott via rscott@eastlothiancourier for details. title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-elphinstone-gifford-haddington-longniddry-tranent
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Elphinstone.  or aschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddingtonAN INCREASING number of people are getting in touch with community resilience volunteers in Haddington.The townrsquos community council and the people I donrsquot know about who are helping as well.ldquoWe have had people who have had maintenance issues and we have managed to get some tradesmen out to them.ldquoTradesmen are offering to help, some doing it for revenue but a couple doing it for nothing people are helping for nothing.Mr McEwan also highlighted that there was a wide range of information on the grouprsquos website, with sections set up to alert people to community help and coronavirus.On top of that, there is a section for food deliveries, ranging from butchers and bakers to prepared meals and takeaways which are open in the town.The community council plans to keep the list as up to date as possible for people.Contact detailsAnyone looking to find out more can visit www.haddingtoncc.org.uk while anyone looking for assistance can e-mail resilienthcc@haddingtoncc.org.uk or call  .Longniddry. title: shop-visit-sting-tail-scorpion-discovered
story: Adrian Nowak, who lives in Musselburgh town centre, found a dead scorpion lying underneath the fruit while out for a recent shopping trip at the supermarket on Newhailes Road."I went to Lidl to get some essentials and I thought about getting melon and found it under one of the melons I picked up - it had been squashed," said Mr Nowak, a chef at a local care home, who bought the melon.A spokesperson for Lidl said: "At Lidl, we pride ourselves on having thorough procedures in place to ensure that our fresh fruit and vegetables are of the highest possible quality for our customers. We are, therefore, disappointed that these expected high standards have not been met on this occasion and would like to sincerely apologise to the customer."We can confirm that it has also been escalated to our Quality Assurance team to investigate further with the supplier."Mr Nowaks photos attracted a lot of interest on social media with one post staying: "I bet you social distanced yourself from that as quickly as possible!"Another read: "When was in Royal Navy we got our stores in foreign ports. Chef checks bananas before go in chilly room, us two stokers there to ensure fridges donrsquot keep tripping. Opens box and spider size of a hand on top unit was alive but, because of being in cool temperatures, it lay still well three guys trying to get up a vertical ladder wasnrsquot easy."One stated: "I was stung by one of them in Guatemala - not pleasant at all."Another said: "Well this story has a sting in the tail.""If you import food from foreign countries its to be expected there are always going to be a few extra guests along for the ride . . . just be alert and be on the lookout, its part of the deal," joked another.
